citations.narrative:
During inspection, members of the general public were seen feeding the two ducks an unknown substance and
attempting to touch the ducks without an attendant present. No barrier was present to prevent the public from interacting
with the animals without supervision. A single sign on the wall directed guests to ask an attendant for assistance. The
attendant on duty was stationed in the adjacent room on the other side of a common wall and out of direct line of sight of
the ducks. Unsupervised handling of animals during public exhibition creates risk of harm to the animal and to the public.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public.
Correct by 26 September 2023.

When asked about the sanitization schedule for the water receptacles for rabbits, the facility representative stated that
they are sanitized once every month or as needed. Failure to sanitize water receptacles at least once every 2 weeks can
lead to reduced water quality and increased risk of illness in animals. All watering receptacles shall be sanitized when
dirty: Provided, however, that such receptacles shall be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks.
Correct by 22 September 2023.

The dry area located under the silk flower decor in the enclosure for the two ducks does not provide adequate freedom of
movement and does not allow for normal postural adjustments. While on the dry area, the ducks would not be able to fully
open their wings in all directions without making contact with the wall of the enclosure. When the facility fed the two ducks
a meal out of a single receptacle, it was observed that only one duck can stand on the dry area and the other must swim
stationary in the pool in order to eat at the same time. Failure to allow adequate freedom of movement on dry areas for
aquatic birds can lead to poor physical and psychological condition of the animals. Primary enclosures housing wading
and aquatic birds must contain a dry area of sufficient size to allow each bird to make normal postural and social
adjustments with adequate freedom of movement and freedom to escape from aggression demonstrated by other birds in
the enclosure.
Correct by 3 October 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
